So said  steffen.gemkow@...  on  2003-01-17
--------------------

>JBR,
>
>thanks for your response. I agree with you, that thinking 
>about a test before implementing the according part of 
>the application is very important. 
>
>I understand you refuse to write a compilable but hollow 
>method of an application method before you write the test. 
>(This would make the use of a test stub generator impossible.) 
>
>There I don't agree. I like the documentation aspect of code 
>related tests. This kind of tests enable me to look at a test 
>in order to understand the intention of an application method. 
>This is very important to me. JUnitDoclet is helping me to 
>keep application structure and test structure in sync, which 
>is essential there. Still I can _implement_ the test method 
>before I _implement_ the application method. 

I'm not sure why writing the test before the stub provides more
documentation than writing the stub before the test.

Also, if you haven't written the test, then how can you be sure that
the stub:

1. ...has the proper signature?
2. ...is named well?
3. ...should be class- or instance-level?
4. ...is written on the appropriate object?

Generally speaking, you don't really know these things until you write
test code, which is really just sample client code, look at it,
evaluate it and move on. In general, it is when one sees it "in print"
than one really looks at it carefully. Writing the test first
guarantees this, while writing the stub first does not.

I don't use JUnitDoclet, so I can't comment on how using it changes the
rules of the game. If it's easy to set up (less than 1 hour), then I
may start using it, just for the experience.

>I believe the core idea of "test before code" is 
>possible with _regenerating_ tools like JUnitDoclet. 
>It just requires some self control.
>
>After all, this is not a major dissagreement. If there 
>wouldn't be that documenting aspect of tests...

I would like you to expand on this: what "documenting aspect" do you
mean? and why does writing the stub first enable this feature and
writing the test first not enable this feature?

Thanks.


J. B. Rainsberger,
